title: 'He hulked out': Burnt out employee smashes $10,000 worth of equipment after upper management snubs their department head's input
description: This office employee reached his boiling point after upper management told his direct boss to stop sharing their input about everyone's workload. When it's the department head who's on the ground in the office sharing insights and feedback from their workers, perhaps you should listen to him instead of setting unattainable quarterly goals."If we want your input, we will ask for it. Period."After getting surveyed by the C-level bosses upstairs, this manager was under heavy scrutiny for his empathetic management tactics. They called for an emergency company-wide meeting just to criticize his managing style, only to realize after $10k worth of damages that he actually had some insightful advice. Keep scrolling to read how out-of-touch upper management paid the price when a lower-level employee snapped under the pressure of their impossible expectations.After this, here's another tale of upper management stupidity where a hiring manager refuses to even look at the job application of a cancer survivor because of the gap in his resume from undergoing chemo.
author: Jesse Kessenheimer

title: Neighbors disagree over 4cm fence measurement: '[My] neighbor was petty... I'm going to make him replace his whole fence'
description: "The law is the law," this person bragged as they made their neighbor replace his whole entire fence. Sometimes the impulse toward pettiness can pay off! U/Sospuff has an awful neighbor who is making a big fuss over the fence the two of them share. It's not an ideal situation: this person has three kids, and the neighbor has a dog that the original poster believes poses a danger. It's understandable that this person would want to protect their kids. However, as they shared in a post to r/pettyrevenge, even though the missing height of the fence is just a few centimeters, they aren't willing to let it go. The neighbor needs a fence that's two meters tall, and his is just under that amount. But since he's been such a pain for this person, including taking him to court before, this person is absolutely not willing to let it go. They posted an update, as well as defending themself from people who criticized their plan. You can read all about it down below! Up next, take a peek into the life of this free-spirited couple who showed up at a family member's house and decided to live there, leading the family member to realize they "didn't sign up to be a hotel."
author: Remy Millisky

title: 23 Fuzzy Feline Memes That Need This Sunday to Become Seriously Sillier and Fluffing Funnier
description: There's a big difference for cat pawrents between the first day of the weekend, where it's all a cute and cuddly Caturday, and the second day of the weekend, where it's a sassy and silly Sunday. On a Caturday, your cat greets you after a whole workweek where you've been away, and all they want is to receive all the pets from you and snuggle endlessly. But on a Sunday, your cat has had enough of this silly nonsense of a silly hooman being in their silly little space for far too long, so they enter the zoomies overdrive.To try and relax yourself and your cat, we prepared a bunch of fuzzy feline memes that you can watch together. And who knows, instead of your cat returning to their Caturday vibes, you might actually catch on to the Sunday sassy vibe and join your cat in the current zoomies session.
author: Ayala Sorotsky

title: Wholesome Husband Buys Unique Cat-Shaped Anniversary Ring For His Feline Fanatic Furrever Partner, Styled After Their Fluffy Fur Babies
description: We're just going to throw it out there for the world to know: men who like cats are a green flag. Cats require learning boundaries, respect, and patience - all qualities that are necessary for a good partner. So, you know that if a man is going to treat your cats well, it's more than likely that he will treat you well, too. So when this wholesome husband decided to buy his wife a five-year anniversary present with a ring unique ring styled after their fluffy fur babies, we just knew it was something so special that we had to share it.Not only does this man love their beautiful black cats, but he also went out and got a custom cat-shaped ring in their honor. Where has this man been hiding his whole life, and why didn't we find him first? From now on, we're only accepting cat-shaped rings for any occasion. Anyway, scroll down to see the ring, the cute kitties, and all the heartwarming love that just pours out of this pawdorable feline post. It's good wholesome fuel to start the week with a happy heart!
author: Blakeseidel

title: The Gambit Gambit
description: Channing Tatum is an incredible Gambit as long as you close your eyes. I can see a scenario where true innovators utilize forced perspective or something but there would be significant challenges. The suit looked uncomfortable; imagine that Channing Tatum were a squeezable product. This is what the tube would look like.

title: Thoughts on 26 Years of Penny Arcade
description: I loved Deadpool and Wolverine, especially the team of forgotten heroes they assembled. I leaned over to Noah in the theater and shook him shouting “BLADE” when Wesley Snipes appeared. While I liked seeing Gambit on screen and I appreciate that Channing Tatum likes the character, I have to say I don’t really see him as Gambit. He tried very hard and I don’t even hate the accent but he just doesn’t physically look like Gambit to me. If they want to get serious I think they need to hire someone like Austin Butler who I think would kill the role accent and all.

title: We’re not going anywhere.
description: I’ve had a lot of people ask if I’m leaving Texas. I totally support those who feel like they need to move for their safety or sanity, but I don’t plan to leave. Perhaps that may change one day but for now I’ll continue to be here…a small blue dot. And Nowhere Bookshop will beContinue reading "We’re not going anywhere."

description: I’ve been in a depression this last week and honestly, I’d probably still be in bed but I made a promise to update my substack every week and it forced me to write, which actually helped in a strange way. Just in case you aren’t signed up for it, here’s what I shared today. I’llContinue reading "I’m not giving up on you or me."

title: Error'd: Tangled Up In Blue
description: ...Screens of Death. Photos of failures in kiosk-mode always strike me as akin to the wizard being exposed behind his curtain. Yeah, that shiny thing is after all just some Windows PC on a stick. Here are a few that aren't particularly recent, but they're real. Jared S. augurs ill: "Seen in downtown Mountain View, CA: In Silicon Valley AI has taken over. There is no past, there is no future, and strangely, even the present is totally buggered. However, you're free to restore the present if you wish."   Windows crashed Maurizio De Cecco's party and he is vexé. "Some OS just doesn’t belong in the parisian nightlife," he grumbled. But neither does pulled pork barbecue and yet there it is.   Máté cut Windows down cold. "Looks like the glaciers are not the only thing frozen at Matterhorn Glacier Paradise..."   Thomas found an installer trying to apply updates "in the Northwestern University's visitor welcome center, right smack in the middle of a nine-screen video display. I can only imagine why they might have iTunes or iCloud installed on their massive embedded display." I certainly can't.   Finally, Charles T. found a fast-food failure and was left entirely wordless. And hungry.   [Advertisement] Picking up NuGet is easy. Getting good at it takes time. Download our guide to learn the best practice of NuGet for the Enterprise.
author: Lyle Seaman

title: CodeSOD: Secondary Waits
description: ArSo works at a small company. It's the kind of place that has one software developer, and ArSo isn't it. But ArSo is curious about programming, and has enough of a technical background that small tasks should be achievable. After some conversations with management, an arrangement was made: Kurt, their developer, would identify a few tasks that were suitable for a beginner, and would then take some time to mentor ArSo through completing them. It sounded great, especially because Kurt was going to provide sample code which would give ArSo a head start on getting things done. What better way to learn than by watching a professional at work? DateTime datTmp; File.Copy(strFileOld, strFileNew); // 2 seconds delay datTmp = DateTime.Now; while (datTmp.Second == DateTime.Now.Second); datTmp = DateTime.Now; while (datTmp.Second == DateTime.Now.Second); File.Delete(strFileOld); This code copies a file from an old path to a new path, and then deletes the old path after a two second delay. Why is there a delay? I don't know. Why is the delay written like this? I can't possibly explain that. Check the time at the start of the loop. When the second part of that time stops matching the second part of the current time, we assume one second has passed. This is, of course, inaccurate- if I check the time at 0:00:00.9999 a lot less than a second will pass. This delay is at most one second. In any case, ArSo has some serious questions about Kurt's mentorship, and writes: Now I don't know if I should ask for more coding tasks. Honestly, I think you should ask for more. Like, I think you should just take Kurt's job. You may be a beginner, but honestly, you're likely going to do a better job than this. title: WNBA Players Forced To Supplement Incomes During Offseason By Cheerleading For NBA Teams
description: MINNEAPOLIS—Grabbing their pom-poms before heading out to pump up the crowd, several WNBA players confirmed Thursday that they have been forced to supplement their incomes during the offseason by cheerleading for NBA teams. “With the season over, everyone in the league is scrambling to make ends meet by getting a second job dancing for the […] The post WNBA Players Forced To Supplement Incomes During Offseason By Cheerleading For NBA Teams appeared first on The Onion.

title: Man Forgetting Difference Between Meteoroid, Meteorite Struggles To Describe What Just Killed His Dog
description: TORONTO—Though he tried hard to recall what he had learned about space rocks back in middle school, local man Jason Nieto reportedly forgot the difference between meteoroids and meteorites Thursday, struggling to describe what had just killed his dog. “God, I always forgot which one is the kind that actually hits the ground, if that’s […] The post Man Forgetting Difference Between Meteoroid, Meteorite Struggles To Describe What Just Killed His Dog appeared first on The Onion.
